texts.shortText:
Shell cap-shaped, fairly tall, right side bulging to accommodate the breathing siphon. External surface brown with 30-40 paler alternating larger and smaller ribs. Ribs characteristically saw-toothed or serrate and projecting distinctly beyond margin of shell. Inner surface brown with distinct white rays radiating though the dark margin.

In living animal dark flecks on side of foot.

Global: Endemic to South Africa (reported record from Madagascar considered unlikely).

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to northern KwaZulu-Natal.

Common on exposed rocks in the mid to upper intertidal, where probably grazes largely on lichens. Does not form a home scar.

The respiratory system in this group is unusual in that they posses a lung-like pulmonary chamber that opens on the right side via a tubular siphon. The inner surface of this chamber is highly vascularised and also contains a secondary gill, allowing the animals to breath both in air and in water. If one turns the animal upside down the siphon can been seen opening and closing much like the opening to the lung of a land snail.
Herbivorous, thought to feed largely on encrusting lichens.

Eggs are laid in a collar attached to the rock adjacent to the colony. In this species each egg mass contains about 1000-2500 eggs, which take 20-28 days to develop and hatch directly into crawling young.

False-limpets can be difficult to identify to species level, but this is one of the more distinctive species due to the serrate ribs that extend beyond the margin. It can be confused with the Ribbed false-limpet S. concinna, but that species has fewer (20-25) external ribs which are never serrate. The interior also has a wide black margin but a white or pale centre and the sides of the foot have white not dark spots.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 170)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 135, as S. aspera).

Chambers, RJ & McQuaid, CD (1994). Notes on the taxonomy, spawn and larval development of South African species of the intertidal limpet Siphonaria (Gastropoda: Pulmonata). Journal of Molluscan Studies, 60(3), 263-275.
